questions.question_text:
An administrator receives a USB drive and wants to make an exact copy of the disk before starting to work on it. One of the partitions on the USB drive was mounted as /dev/sdc1.
Which of the following commands should the administrator use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think it's D, with mdadm you need to grow the array, otherwise the drive will just be used as a spare in the RAID array

comments.content:
This is confirmed when viewing the output of cat /proc/mdstat in the question:
md0 : active Raid sdd1[3]S sdc1[2] sdb1[1] sda1[0]
where the new drive sdd1 has 'S' for Spare as a suffix.

After adding it as a spare, then mdadm --grow... can be run, and after that a tool like resize2fs can be run to finally increase the space available to users on the array.

choices.A: Run hdparm to alert the kernel to a new drive.
choices.D: Grow the array size to four members.
choices.C: Set the RAID type to a RAID 1.
choices.B: Convert the new drive to a hot spare.

discussion.content:
IP forwarding is often used in conjunction with iptables firewall configuration.
In order to leverage IP forwarding, you must first enable it in the kernel.
